details.title: Optimal step-stress test under progressive type-I censoring
details.standardTitle: Optimal step-stress test under progressive type-I censoring

p: Evans Gouno received a Ph.D. in Mathematics from the University of Marne-la-Valle (France) in 1996 while he was a Research Engineer in the Department of Technology and Reliability of Thomson-CSF. At the present time, he is an Associate Professor at University of South Brittany in France where he teaches Statistic and Probability. His area of research are reliability, survival analysis, Bayesian inference and stochastic processes.

authors.affiliation: Univ. of South Brittany, Vannes, France
authors.name: E. Gouno

p: Ananda Sen is an Associate Research Scientist at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, Michigan. He received his M.S. in Statistics in 1987 from Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata, India and Ph.D. in Statistics in 1993 from University of Wisconsin, Madison. His major research interests include life-testing and reliability, analysis of competing risks data, and Bayesian inference.

N. Balakrishnan is Professor of Statistics in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at McMaster University. He received his Ph. D. in 1981 from the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India. He has been at McMaster University since 1985. His research interests include order statistics, statistical inference and distribution theory. He is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association and currently the Editor-in Chief of Communications in Statistics and the Encyclopedia of Statistical Sciences.

details.abstract: We consider in this work a k-step-stress accelerated test with equal duration steps /spl tau/. Censoring is allowed at each change stress point i/spl tau/, i=1,...k. The problem of choosing the optimal /spl tau/ is addressed using variance optimality as well as determinant-optimality criteria. We investigate in detail the case of progressively Type-I right censored data with a single stress variable.

citations.title: Optimal step-stress test under progressive type-I censoring

links.abstract: This paper presents optimum plans for simple (two stresses) step-stress tests where all units are run to failure. Such plans minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) of the mean life at a design stress. The life-test model consists of: 1) an exponential life distribution with 2) a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and 3) a cumulative exposure model for the effect of changing stress. Two types of simple step-stress tests are considered: 1) a time-step...

context.text: Miller and Nelson [1] initiated research in this area by assuming complete failure data under two stress levels (simple step-stress) and the assumption of exponential lifetimes.

references.title: Optimum simple step-stress plans for accelerated life testing
references.text: R. Miller, W. Nelson, "Optimum simple step-stress plans for accelerated life testing", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 32, pp. 59-65, 1983.

links.abstract: This paper presents statistical models and methods for analyzing accelerated life-test data from step-stress tests. Maximum likelihood methods provide estimates of the parameters of such models, the life distribution under constant stress, and other information. While the methods are applied to the Weibull distribution and inverse power law, they apply to many other accelerated life test models. These methods are illustrated with step-stress data on time to breakdown of an electrical insulation.

context.text: The basic model used was the one proposed by Nelson [2], and is referred to in the literature as the Cumulative Exposure (CE) model.

references.title: Accelerated life testing-step-stress models and data analysis
references.text: W. Nelson, "Accelerated life testing-step-stress models and data analysis", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-29, pp. 103-108, 1980.

links.abstract: The authors present the optimum simple time-step and failure-step stress accelerated life tests for the case where a prespecified censoring time is involved. An exponential life distribution with a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. The authors obtain the optimum test plans to minimize the asymptotic variance of the maximum-likelihood estimator of the mean life at a design stress. Nomographs for the optimum time-step stress test are also gi...

context.text: Extension of the results to the time-censored case, and the case of three stress levels, were obtained by Bai, Kim, & Lee [3], and Khamis & Higgins [4], respectively.

references.title: Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests with censoring
references.text: D. S. Bai, M. S. Kim, S. H. Lee, "Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life tests with censoring", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 38, pp. 528-532, 1989.

links.abstract: Optimum simple step-stress accelerated life testing plans have practical limitations. They highly depend upon the assumption of a linear relationship between stress and time-to-failure and use only two extreme stresses that can cause irrelevant failure modes. Thus, 3-step plans are preferable. In this paper, the authors derive the optimum quadratic plan and propose and evaluate a 3-step test plan, the compound linear, as an alternative to the optimum simple step-stress plan and optimum quadratic...

context.text: Extension of the results to the time-censored case, and the case of three stress levels, were obtained by Bai, Kim, & Lee [3], and Khamis & Higgins [4], respectively.

references.title: Optimum 3-step step-stress tests
references.text: I. H. Khamis, J. J. Higgins, "Optimum 3-step step-stress tests", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 45, pp. 341-345, 1996.

links.abstract: The mathematical intractability of the Weibull cumulative exposure model (CE-M) has impeded the development of statistical procedures for step-stress accelerated life tests. Our new model (KH-M) is based on a time transformation of the exponential CE-M. The time-transformation enables the reliability engineer to use known results for multiple-step, multiple-stress models that have been developed for the exponential step-stress model. KH-M has a realistically appealing proportional-hazard propert...

context.text: For the general \$k\$-level, \$M\$-variable case, some numerical investigation was undertaken by Khamis [5].

references.title: A new model for step-stress testing
references.text: I. H. Khamis, J. J. Higgins, "A new model for step-stress testing", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 47, pp. 131-134, 1998.

context.text: Khamis and Higgins [6] also considered the problem under a Weibull distribution for the lifetimes of units subjected to stress.

references.title: Optimum M-step, step-stress test with
references.text: I. H. Khamis, " Optimum M-step step-stress test with \$k\$ stress variables ", Communications in Statistics̵Computation and Simulation, vol. 26, pp. 1301-1313, 1997.

links.abstract: A sequential approach is presented to plan a multiple-steps step-stress accelerated life test (SSALT) with type-I censoring so as to achieve a pre-specified acceleration factor. An initial optimal plan for a simple SSALT, where one not only has to determine the optimum hold-time under low stress but also the optimum low stress level, is obtained by solving a constrained nonlinear program. A backward recursion scheme generates the subsequent optimal low-stress levels and hold-times for multiple-s...

context.text: Yeo and Tang [7] investigated the optimality problem in the situation, wherein a target acceleration factor is prespecified.

references.title: Planning step-stress life-test with a target acceleration-factor
references.text: K.-P. Yeo, L.-C. Tang, "Planning step-stress life-test with a target acceleration-factor", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 48, pp. 61-67, 1999.

links.abstract: This paper presents the inferences of parameters on the simple step-stress model in accelerated life testing with type-II censoring. An exponential life distribution with a mean that is a log-linear function of stress, and a cumulative exposure model are assumed. Maximum likelihood methods are used to estimate the parameters of these models. Hypothesis tests about model parameters are discussed. Confidence intervals for parameter-estimates are constructed using a pivotal quantity. The advantage ...

context.text: Inference issues with the CE model under exponentiality were studied by Xiong [8], and Xiong and Milliken [9].

references.title: Inferences on a simple step-stress model with Type-II censored exponential data
references.text: C. Xiong, "Inferences on a simple step-stress model with Type-II censored exponential data", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 47, pp. 142-146, 1998.

links.abstract: This paper studies statistical models in step-stress accelerated life-testing when the stress-change times are random. The marginal lifetime distribution of a test unit under a step-stress test plan when the stress change times are random variables is presented. Maximum likelihood estimates for model parameters based on both the marginal and conditional life distributions are considered. An optimum test plan is explored for simple step-stress test when the stress change time is an order statisti...

context.text: Inference issues with the CE model under exponentiality were studied by Xiong [8], and Xiong and Milliken [9].

references.title: Step-stress life-testing with random stress-change times for exponential data
references.text: C. Xiong, G. A. Milliken, "Step-stress life-testing with random stress-change times for exponential data", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 48, pp. 141-148, 1999.

context.text: For a concise review of step-stress accelerated life tests, readers may refer to Gouno and Balakrishnan [10].

references.title: Step-stress accelerated life test
references.text: N. Balakrishnan, C. R. Rao, "Step-stress accelerated life test" in Handbook of Statistics Vol. 20: Advances in Reliability, pp. 623-639, 2001, North-Holland.

context.text: Cohen [11] describes one such modification where the actual number of progressively censored items at each stage is the minimum of \$c_{i}\$, and the available number of items at that stage.

references.title: Truncated and Censored Samples: Theory and Applications
references.text: A. C. Cohen, Truncated and Censored Samples: Theory and Applications, 1991, Marcel Dekker.
